bibl.title: Letter from Walter Reed to Blossom Reed, July 25, 1900

div1.p: Reed teases his daughter Blossom Reed. He expects to leave Cuba on August 1 or 2.

div1.head: Letter from Walter Reed to Blossom Reed, July 25, 1900
div1.opener:
C1
B9
No. 23
Wednesday night.
Brother is very well.
Camp Columbia,
Quemados, Cuba,
July 25, 1900.
My precious little big Daughter;
div1.p:
Your
very sweet and interesting
letter, written on the 21st of July,
was received this noon and
was enjoyed so much. It was
a great improvement on the
one you wrote before, when
it was so hot and my little
joy was so disgusted with
the weather-man. Would you
believe that I am sitting
here with my blue blouse
on? It was so chilly before
dinner that I took off my
linen blouse & put on a
warm one- If you want
to enjoy a pleasant summer,
come down to Cuba- Papa
was so glad to hear that
his darling daughter and
Sir Skeeny's best girl are
having such a good time,
driving and going to church
etc- Of course you are
expecting Sir Skeeny's and Sir
Francis de Smoot to come up
for a short visit while
the beautiful young lady
from “Anna Polis” is on
the Mountain! what flirtations
and giggles there would
be! Father is distressed to
hear that your dear aunt
Jane isn't well- You must
be very sweet to her and nurse
her back to health- Make her
one of those nice mint-Juleps
which you know so well how
to make- Never mind, Papa
will come soon himself
and cheer her up. You folks
don't know how to take care
of Sis Mottsay- Wait till Papa
gets there, and she will be as
frisky as a kitten- Why did
not your sweet young Mother
write to me this time, too? I
guess her letters will come
to-morrow- Tell Mother that
Father is going down to take
a noon breakfast with our
English Cousins in Havana
tomorrow. Papa hears that a
Transport will sail about
August the 1st or 2nd and if
that is true, you and dearest
Mother may look out for me
the 7th or 8th, depending upon
the chances speed the vessel will
make- So you need not an-
swer this letter- I tell you,
your dearest Papa is very
anxious to see his sweet
girls once more, and to
taste some of those good
vegetables; but his stay in
Cuba has been so much
more pleasant than he had
anticipated- Papa thinks that,
as the mail doesn't leave
till Saturday the 28th, you
will not get it till about
August 1st or 2nd, at which
time he hopes to start back,
Give much love to aunt Jane &
Helen -- also to the aunties & the
girls when you see them-
Forty kisses for sweet mother,
Love & kisses for my precious
babies-
